justification: "In Australia, umpiring performance is assessed using a 'percentage correct' metric based on accuracy ratings made after the match by a match referee who reviews video footage after the match and determines whether the on-field umpire made the correct decision."

"We assess umpire performance using a signal detection paradigm (Green & Swets, 1966) to take into account the multiple ways to be right (hits and correct rejections) and wrong (misses and false alarms)."

"These hit and false alarm rates were log-linear corrected and then combined to form measures of sensitivity (A)… Sensitivity scores range from 0 to 1, with 0.5 meaning chance discrimination between outs and not outs."

"These hit and false alarm rates were… combined to form measures of… response bias (B)… Bias scores less than 1 indicate liberal response bias and scores greater than 1 indicate conservative response bias."

measured_by: hit rate and false alarm rate
justification: "The hit rate represents each umpire's performance when the batter should have been given out… The false alarm rate represents how often umpires erroneously give a batter out when they should have been given not out."
